From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> Yes, the echo/atom API work is in fact what
> started me thinking about MoST.  My point is that
> we should not need an Atom API and a RSS API and a
> Wiki API and a RNA/Notification API and a Foo API.

So you are saying that I should be able to have an uber-client that would
know how to act with *any* resource merely be examing its schema?

> If servers exposed the underlying data model in a
> consistent syntactic format, e.g. XML then the
> only API you would need is the API for
> manipulating that syntactic model.  The meaning of
> changes to the model would be defined entirely by
> the XML schema.

Does this mean that the client is then in total control of the resource or
does the server still do its own checks to ensure resource integrity?

> So, if you change from Atom to Pie to RSS.91 to
> RSS2 to RNA to ...., the API shouldn't change.
> Its always be GET/PUT/POST/DELETE against XML node
> ids and you know that this is the API because the
> content-type is text/XML!

Whoa!  What does RNA have to do with Pie/RSS?  If that's what you think RNA
is about, you have totally missed the point behind RNA.  Sure, some facets
of blog systems (not RSS/Pie) could be implemented with RNA (which is what
my http://www.seairth.com/blog/industry/49 post was hinting at, though not
very successfuly).  But, to my knowledge, RNA is not interchangable with
*any* other specification I am aware of, regardless of how exposed you make
the data model.

> My objection to ReST is precisely that:
> 1. there is no way to know the API a URI exposes
> without out-of-band communication

True, but there is also no way to use any part of the web without at least
an initial amount of out-of-band communication.  And there have been
proposals such as Roger Costello's (et al.) Meta-Location header to help
expose information such as this.  It's not perfect, but it's a start...

> 2. GET/PUT/POST/DELETE have no consistent
> *meaning* accross URI so API documentation ends up
> being extensive.

What do you mean by no consistent meaning?  Regardless of the application
used, I know the meaning of a GET.  I may not know what the results mean,
but I certainly know what the request means.  The same is pretty much true
for the other methods as well.  Now, I agree that they don't necessarily
have consistent implementation across URIs (e.g. some support only GET while
others support GET and PUT), but that's what an API (or RI or whatever) and
the HTTP 405 response is for (plus Allowed header).

> You have 13 pages of documentation simply to
> update an XML document with a well defined schema.
> You are clearly a smart person. You should find it
> frustrating to be spending your time writing such
> a document and your should find it even more
> frustrating to think about the number of
> programmers who have to spend time reading and
> understanding that document for your time
> investment to pay-off.

Why not define a computer-processable schema language for RESTful
interfaces?  Then, you could just generate the appropriate wrapper code at
the push of a button based on such a schema.  Wouldn't a MoSTful schema
basically provide the same thing?
